div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,239] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, November 13, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.

R.M.S. “Oroya" will leave Port Said December 3

HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular three-weekly Service from HAMBURG, via ANTWERP & MALTA, to ALEXANDRIA and vice-versa, admitting goods from all chief German Railway Stations on direct Bill of Landing to ALEXANDRIA and all chief ports of Egypt, Syria, etc., at favourable through rates of DEUTSCHE VERKEHR (traffic).
EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.
S.S. Woglinde November 16 from Antwerp.
For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria, Agent.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Saturday, November 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l7th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: CAPITAL FRANCS 250,000,000 ENTIEREMENT VERSES
Agences d’Egypte : ALEXANDRIE, LE CAIRE, PORT-SAID.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que : Avances sur titres fixes et en compte courant, Avances sur marchandises et consignations, Emission de traités et chèques, Emission de lettres de Crédit, Paiements par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France èt de l’étranger, Garde de titres Recouvrement d’effets sur l’Egypte et l'étranger ; le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds en compte de depôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe au taux de 3 o/o pour 1 an et au-delà. 31-12-906

div.head: COMPTOIR NATIONAL D’ESCOMPTE
div.p: DE PARIS.
CAPITAL: 150,000,000 frs,-£ 6,000,000 FULLY PAID UP. — HEAD OFFICE: 14, Rue Bergere, Paris
Alexandria Branch 11, Rue Cherif Pacha.—40 Branches in Paris, and 112 Throughout France.

Branches in London, Liverpool, Manchester, Morocco, Tunis, East India, Madagascar, Australia, etc. Bills Collected. Deposit Accounts opened at sight & for fixed periods, Advances on securities, in current account. Letters of Credit and Telegraphic Transfers Issued. Foreign Exhange Bought and Sold. Stocks and Valuables received in safe custody. Purchase and Sale of Stock & Shares in Egypt and Abroad. Dividends Collected.

div.head: BANK OF ATHENS, LIMITED.
div.p: Head Office : Athens — Capital 20,000.000 (Fully paid up). — Reserve 1,000,000.

Patras, Yolo, Syra, Calamata. The Bank undertakes all banking business in Egypt, Greece, etc. Interests on cash deposits,
3 0/0 per ann. at sight; 3 1/2 0/0 per ann. for 6 months; 4 0/0 per ann. for 12 months; 5 0/0 per ann. for 3 years and over. Savings
Bank Branch receives deposits at 3 1/2 0/0 per ann., from P.T. 80 to P.T. 20,000. 19-1-907

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: Capital: £3,000,000. RESERVE (Environ) : £1,340,000. MR. F. T. ROWLATT, Governor

Siège Social au Caire, Succursale à Alexandria, Agence à Assiout, Assuoan, Benha, Beni-Suef, Chibin el Kom, Damanhour, Fayoum, Khartoum, Kéneh, Mansourah, Minieh, Port-Said, Suakin, Sohag, Tantah, Zagazig, Mouski (Caire) et Londres (4 et 5, King William Street). La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s’occupe de l’achat et de la vente d'effets sur l’Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-906

div.head: CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN
div.p: Capital 12,500,000 Francs entièrement verses. — Agence d’Alexandrie, 14, Rue Stamboul.

LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN fait toutes opérations de Banque, notamment: Escompte d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'etranger. Avance sur titres.—Garde de titres.—Depots de fonds a vue et à échéance fixe avec intérêts aux taux suivants: 2 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts de 6 mois, 3 0/0 pour dépôts d’un an, 3 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts au délà d’un an. — LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN reçoit des Marchandises en consignation pour la vente et fait des Avances sur Cotons, Grains et autres marchandises. — 28337-10-8-907

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 10 and 24 October, 7 and 21 November, 5 and 19 December.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 8 and 22 October, 5 and 19 November, 3, 17 and 31 December.
Syrian-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 1, 15 and 29 October, 12 and 26 November, 10 and 24 December.
Far East Lines.
Departures from Port Said: To Suez, Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama and Kobé, 4 October, 3 November.
To Suez, Aden and Bombay accelerated service about 8 October, 8 Nov., 8 Dec.
To Suez, Aden, Karachi, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about 19 Oct, 3, 19 Nov., 19 Dec 4 p.m.
To Suez, Aden, Karachi and Bombay about 13 Nov., 1 Dec (Winter Line).
East African Line.
Departures from Port Said: To Suez, Aden, Mombassa, Zanzibar, Beira, Delagoa-Bay, and Durban about 3 Oct., 2 Nov., 3 Dec..
For information apply to the Agents, Alexandria, Port Said and Suez, Thos. Cook & Son, Ld., Leon Heller, Cairo Agent, 24, Sharia Maghraby, (Telephone 192), Cairo; F. Tedeschi, Helouan.
Special rates for Egyptian officials, members of Army of Occupation and their families.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: Egyptian State Railways.
div.p: †Dining Car. §Sleeping Car. ‡First and Second Class only.
* Dining and Sleeping Cars are attached to these trains on the following days: -- From Cairo, every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday. From Luxor, every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.
J. H. l'E. JOHNSTONE, General Manager.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER.”

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature’s Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray’s Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

L’Administration des Chemins do fer de l’Etat a l’hcnneur d’irformer le Public que l’ad-mission des apprentis aux A teliers des Chemins de Fer sera gratuite, jnrqn’a nouvel avi , c'e t- k-dire qu’elle sefera sans paiement de la prime . de LE 5 pre'alablement fixe'e.
La dure'e de l’apprentissage sera de oitq anodes et le salaire pendant cette pe'riode sera comme suit:
Pour les six premiers mois sans paie Pour les six mois suivants 20 m/m par jour Poor la seconde anne'e 40 , „ „

Poor la quatrie'me anne'e 60 „ „ „

Lea apprentis ne doivent pas etre Ages de moins de 14 ans. ni de plus de 16.
Ils doivent, avant , etre exnmines par un medeoin de l’Administration et passer un examen de lecture, d’decriture et d’arithme- tiqne e'ementaire.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
div.p: The English Daily Newspaper.
Established 1880
Editor and Manager - R. SNELLING
PRICE: 1 PLASTRE TARIFF
TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1906
THE MAGNETIC NORTH.

When Dr. Nansen visited England after his last long sojourn in the Arctic night, he pointed out that he had left nearly four degrees between his “Farthest North” and the Polo itself to be covered by English enterprise. The margin has been twice reduced in the inter­vening years - on the first occasion by the Duke of the Abruzzi’s expedition, and on the second through the indomitable persistence of Com­mander Peary. That gallant American sailor has crowned his fifth expedition into the unknown by reaching a latitude of 87 deg. 6 min. N., or within 203 miles of the spot which eye hath not seen, but towards which human wonder stretches with an indefatigable yearn­ing. Commander Perry’s success (for in this connection success is still expressed in degrees

div.head: P & O WEEKLY MAIL and PASSENGER SERVICES P & O

Passengers can embark on Monday evening in the Brindisi steamer, which is timed to leave Port Said on Tuesday morning immediately after arrival of the homeward Indian Mail.

HASELDEN & Co. ... .. ... ...ALEXANDRIA.

F. G. DAVIDSON, Suez.

of failure) has filled his countrymen with ft very excusable gratification. The Arctic “record” has been achieved by “an American explorer, an American vessel, and an American route,” and Englishmen will add their congratulations all the more cordially with the knowledge that the captain of the good ship Roosevelt chose to man her with a Newfoundland crew. The journey, says the “Pall Mall Gazette,” has produced additions to the lore of geography of which only a vague impression is yet con­veyed by the brief telegraphic reports of its experience. Land boundaries have apparently been discovered which will set the map-makers to work again, and on the recondite subject of ocean currents Commander Peary will have further additions to make to that important body of facts which was brought home by Dr. of Nansen. The steady progress of the art of ex­ploration is shown by the successful provision against contingencies through which the leader of this latest venture has been able to return ’ with the whole membership of his expedition r safe and sound. Violent gales interfered with certain of its plans, and one of the supporting parties was rescued only when it had reached the confines of starvation. But Peary, like Nansen, has avoided paying the tribute of life * either to disease or hardship, and has thus done much to weaken the objections which Philis­tine philosophy is too prone to urge against the prosecution of Arctic adventure.

The new “record’’-holder of the Far North will have something to say, doubtless, on the possibilities of ultimately reaching the Pole as they seem to be affected by his own exploit. That the boundaries of the “undiscovered country” have been pushed backwards by nearly sixty miles in ten years encourages further persistence in the dream of a cen­tury. On the other hand the obstacles to sledge-travel for more than a certain distance from their base, of which both Peary and Nansen have gained such full experience, inspire obvious doubts as to the remaining two hundred miles being within the compass of possibility. Speculation may turn again towards the balloon or airship plan, and it is noteworthy that the tragedy of Andre’s fate has not prevented other projects of a similar kind from being pressed forward. Mr. Wellman proposes to make his start by the aerial route next year, and his scheme would appear to involve the conjoint potentialities of brilliant success and hopeless disaster. With good fortune a dash across the Pole might be conceivably possible where there are no weary weeks to be consum­ed in the labours of painful and arduous transport; at the same time, such a gale as Commander Peary encountered beyond the 85th parallel would presumably mean the end of all things for the aeronaut who fell in with its tender mercies. In any case, the pursuit of the Pole will not cease to enlist the energies of the harder nations and of those peoples which aspire to lead the world either in Empire or knowledge. It is a symptom of degeneracy, whenever such enter­prise comes to be slighted as a mere form of infatuation. Arctic exploration is in no sense a fruitless expenditure of life and energy in the cause of vain glory. It holds the key to many secrets for which Science is clamorous, and its risks are only those which races with the instinct of conquest are ever ready to court for their ideals. The Arctic field is almost neglected just now by Englishmen, though we can happily point to the records of the Discovery and the Scotia at the earth’s other extremity in proof that the spirit of Franklin, Parry, McClure and Nares is not extinguished. The great Ice Wars are not the least important test of national vita­lity, anti if the races for the Poles are never to be won, the country which can claim to be foremost in them still holds no empty honour.

div.head: LOCAL and general.
div.p: Jerusalem’s Progress.
Advisors from Jerusalem report that the ravines within and without the Gate of Abraham are to be filled up and built over.
The Pilgrimage
The Wakfs Administration is making pre­parations to send a medical mission to assist the poor pilgrims during the forthcoming pilgrimage.
Wakfs Administration.
The Superior Council of the Wakts Admini­stration will meet in Cairo after the Bevram holidays under the presidency of Adly Pasha Yaghen.
Transport.
Some details of the 66th Battery Royal Field Artillery embark at Port Said on the transport Assaye on the 18th inst. for passage to Bombay.
Antiquities for Turin.
Professor Schiaparelli has returned to Tnrin with two hundred cases of Egyptian antiquities the contents of which are shortly to be exhibit­ed in the Museum of that town.
Alhambra Theatre
The Silvestre French comedy company will shortly open a series of ten performances at this theatre. The repertoire includes “Cyrano de Bergerac,” “Napoleon,” “Le Juif Errant,” and ‘ Le Boson.”
Prinoe'8 Birthday.
The 8th birthday of Prince Mohamed Abdel- Moneim, the Heir Apparent was privately celebrated last Tuesday at Montszah Palace, where the Koran ayats were intoned and alms distributed among the poor.
Tourists.

The French yacht lie de France arrived at Alexandria from Marseilles this morning with 150 Cook’s ‘personally-condnoted” French tourists on hoard.The party are on an excursion organised by the “Revue Generate Sciences” of Paris and are leaving Cairo by the 4 25 p m. train to day. After visiting Cairo and Upper Egypt they will rejoin the yacht at Port Said for Jaffa on a visit to the Holy Land.
Suez Canal.
On the 10th and 11th November 19 vessels,
7 northward and 12 southward bound, transited the Canal, and paid transit and passenger toll Fr.462,967.49. Of these vessels, 14 were British,
1 German, 2 Norwegian, 1 Dutch, and 1 Russian. The total revenue since November 1 is Fr. 2,793,241.52. Daring th:s period, 107 vessels transited the Canal, 53 northward and 54 southward bound.
Zizinla Theatre.

Mme. Jane Hading, the distinguished French actress, arrived with her company this morn-ing by the French steamer and will make her debat at the Zizinia Theatre this evening with Dumas’ comedy “La Princesse Georges,” j in which she will take the title rote. This fascinating tbree-act comedy will be pre­ceded by a short “ curtain-raiser, ’’ M. de Ferandy’s “Tic a Tic,” the two characters of which will be taken by Mile. Sauer and M. | Bary. j
Beyram Holidays.

We draw the attention of oar readers to the facilities afforded by the management of the Tewfik Palace Hotel at Helouan for this year’s ; holiday season. The hotel will no doubt, as usual, be the rendez-vous of a great many residents and government officials, who are granted reduced terms. The race-conrsc of the Helouan Sporting Club presents an animated scene every morning and attracts a Urge number of those interested from the Tewfik and other hotels. The golf course and tennis court are in good order. The railway service is now in such excellent working order that nothing on that score remains to be done.
NOUVELLE SOCIETE

div.head: RECOGNITIOiN FOR SERVICES,
div.p: THE TA LODI CAMPAIGN.

The Sirdar publishes in an Army Order the following list of officers and N.C.O.’s whose names have been brought to the notice of H H the Khedive for their good services in connec tion with the recent operations at Talodi in Southern Kordofan : —

Miralai J. R. O’Connell Bey, Commanding the Expedition ; Kaimukam C. H. Leveson Bey, Intelligence Officer ; Bimbashi B. W. Y. Danford, Staff Officer; Bimbashi B. H. S. Romelly, D. S. 0., Camel Corps ; Local Sagh- kolaghasi Mohamed Effendi Wiflri, El Yuzba- shi Hnesein Effendi Mohamed Mustapha, El Mutez:m Awal Abd El Rahman Effendi Sirri, El Mulezim Tani Mohamad Effendi Tewfik Shukri, Bash Shawish Abdulla Gabriel, (all of Camel Corps) ; El Bimbashi Mohamed Effendi Ahmed, El Yuzbashi Mohamed Effendi Suleiman, El Mulazim Tani Mustapha Effendi Maher, No. 1874, Shawi h Faragalla Sudani, (all of 12th Sudanese) ; and El Mulaz’m Tani El Sayed Effendi Ferid, Sudan Government.
THE KHEDIVE
LEILET EL KADR.

The Khedive arrived at Ras el Tin Palace from Montazab at one o’clock this afternoon. This evening his Highness assists at the Leilet el Kadr( ‘Night of Power”) ceremony at Abon el Abbas Mosque, which will also be attended by the Governor of Alexandria, the Ulema, and all the native notabilities of Alexandria.
In Cairo the ceremony will be held at the Citadel Mosque, and the Khedive will be represented by his brother, Prince Mohamed Aly.
DEATH OF LORD CONGLETON.
A telegram from London announces the death of Lord Congleton, brother of the Hon. Mrs. Henry Hopkinson, wife of Miralai Hop- kinson Bey, which occurred in London yester­day.

Major General Henry Parnell, Lord Congle- ' ton, was the second son of the 3rd Baron, and , grandson of Col. the Hon. William Bligh. He was born in 1839 and succeeded his father in 1896. On leaving Sandhurst he passed into the Buffs and served in the Crimea and Zululand, and from 1895 to 1900 he commanded the Infantry Brigade at Gibraltar; in the latter year he was transferred to Malta, and he retired from the Service two years later. In 1885 he married Elizabeth, daughter of Dugald Dove, of Nutshill, Renfrew.
Lord Congleton is succeeded by his eldest son, the Hon. Henry Bligh Fortescue Parnell, who was born in September 1890.
THE PLAGUE.
During the week ending last Saturday,
’ seven cases of plague were notified throughout Egypt, viz., 2 at Alexandria, 2 at Port Said, 1 at Suez, 1 in the Samallout district (Minieh), 1 in the Tantah district.

Five deaths took place during the week, three of which occurred outside hospital. Three recoveries are recorded, all of which were European oases treated at Alexandria, and eleven cases remained under treatment.
• Since January there have been in all 525 cases of plague, as compared with 265 and 824 during the corresponding periods of 1905 and 1904 respectively.
To day’s plague bulletin reports two recov- eries, one of which occured at Alexandria and the other at Samallout, and one admis­sion to hospital at Suez One case at Suez ended fatally yesterday.
PROVINCIAL MUNICIPALITIES.
Of late years the provincial municipalities of Egypt have increased in number consider­ably. The latest town to solicit municipal self-

list.item: government is Emeh, and the question is now being considered by the Ministry of the Interior.

div.p: The creation of municipalities in the small towns of the Interior can hardly be considered quite satisfactory as yet In his last report, attached to that of the Ministry of Public Work, Mr. Perry, as in his previous one, criticises un favourably the work done by these municipalities and in connection therewith Sir William Garstin remark-: “I have no doubt whatever that his are just, and that the quality of this work leaves much to be desired. Also, that some of the expenditure may not unfairly be styled waste of morey. Nevertheless, the experiment of local self- government is worth continuing. Time and patient instruction will doubtless improve matters.”
THE DIANA RECOMMISSIONED i * ——
The cruiser Diana (Captain R. S. Phipps Hornby, C.M.G.) wus paid off on Tuesday last week at Devonport on her return from the Mediterranean Station, for which she was re-

comnnis ioned on the following day. Her crew, which joinedii her in September 1904, was granted thirty-nine days’ leave. It will be remembered that it was the Diana which per­fumed naval honours at the opening of Port Sudan last January, and was afterwards sta- tioned off Akaba during the Sinai frontier crisis.

Built In 1904. Modern House. Splendid situation. Eectric Light

Rooms and Breakfast P.T. 25.— Meals a la Cart

div.head: THE MODERN EGYPTIAN.
div.p: HIS MANNERS AND MORALS.
To the Editor of the “Egyptian Gazette.”

Dear Sir,—“A1 Moayad” has published an interesting reply to my last tetter, the author of which points out that generalisation is nsnally unjust. This I admit again, and again point out that in any community the majority does generalise and mutt generalise. It has not the time, the judgment, or, I fear, the desire to do otherwise.

1 am quite ready to subscribe to “Al Moayad’s” opinion that women of all na­tionalities are absolutely safe from molesta­tion in the shops of the principal Arab traders. Indeed, I consider the Moslem merchants of Cairo to be in manners and morals far superior to the classes that are ranked above them. But when ladies who understand Arabic are lucky if they can pass in front of certain cates, etc., situated in the most respectable quar­ters of Cairo, without hearing the most atro­cious comments, every section of the Euro­pean community which cares for the honour of its women and their freedom from mo­lestation will naturally form a low opinion of the whole class to which the ribald imperti- neuta belong. It is, moreover, unfortunately true that those who are the worst offenders in this respect are not ignorant workmen or fellaheen, but men possessed of some means and education, often holders of grades—in fact, corresponding to the upper middle class of European countries.

My critic remarks : “We recognise the excellent character borne by Englishwomen of the upper classes. Cannot their very virtues im­pose respect ?” True, in theory. But in practice self-respecting men are extremely unwilling to take the risk that their wives or sisters will succeed in imposing this respect on all their Moslem visitors. They argue that if men belonging to ‘a superior class” of Egyptian can insult respectable women in public - and these insults are unhappily too frequent just now—it is best to avoid close social relations with that class for the present. I grant that in many cases the generalisation is unjust, but it is based upon certain well-known facts. H.H. Princess Nazli Hanem is quoted by Mr. de Guerville as giving a very unfavourable opi­nion of the class to which I refer.

Finally, I should like to point out to my Egyptian critics that the women of the country are extraordinarily free from insult on.the part of Europeans, and that on the principle of reciprocity it is only reasonable that European women should claim and deserve the same immunity.—I am, etc.,
Gael.
Cairo.
MAHOMEDANS IN INDIA.

It is stated that it is settled in effect that the Mahomedans of India shall hold an annual gathering to counterbalance in some measure the National Congress of the Hindus. The Aga Khan and the Nawab of Dacca are at the head of this movement, which is one of the most significant that has taken place in India for many years past. A scheme for the con­ference has been prepared by the Nawab of Dacca, and is to be submitted for confirmation to the principal Moslem societies of India. No centre for the holding of'this Mahomedan Congress has yet been selected, but the choice is thought to be between Agra and Lahore. It is hoped that incidentally this conference will be the means every year of raising at least a lakh of rupees for he Mussulman charities.
MILITARY MOVES.
Lieut. A.B. Wilkie, 2nd Battalion Royal Sussex Regiment, who arrived at Alexandria from Crete a few days ago, will embark on the transport Sicilia at Port Said on the 16th inst. en route for Peking.
Captain R. S. Bostock, R.A.M.C., will also embark on the Sicilia for duty daring the outward and homeward voyages of that vessel.
MOTOR BOATS FOR EGYPT.

In our issue of October 23 we mentioned the fact that Messrs. Dixon Bros, and Hut­chinson, consulting engineers, of Woolston, Southampton, were sending three motor boats, designed and built by the firm, to Alexandria and Caro, and fall particulars of the boats were then given.

These boats will remain in Alexandria for one week and permission to view them can be obtained by applying at the offices of Messrs. James Carroll Wilcocks and Co., 12, rue Mahmoud Pasha el Falaki, the agents of Messrs. Dixon Bros, and Hutchinson for Egypt and the Sudan, to whom all necessary arrange­ments for the reception of the beats have been entrusted. Messrs. Dixon Bros, and Hutchinson intend to sell all three boats if possible in either Alexandria or Cairo, but before selling in Alexandria they reserve the right of running the boats to Cairo and back by the Mahmou- dieh Canal. There are already two sailing yachts designed and built by this firm in the harbour, namely, Isis II. and Banshee II., both of which have been most successful.
The S.S. Adalia, with the two boats on board is expected to arrive-on Friday, the 16th inst.

We must congratulate Messrs. Dixon and Hutchinson on their enterprise and wish them every success in introducing what seems likely to become a most important business in Egypt, the Upper Nite, and the Sudan.

div.head: EGYPTIAN PATRIOTISM.
div.p: LACK OF UNITY

Mahmoud Taher Effendi Haki is the author of an interesting article upon the much dis- cussed question of Egyptian patriotism, in which he attributes its feebleness to the aloof­ness of the classes of the people.

It is not open to doubt, he says, that the Egyptians love their country and devoutly wish her to reach the level of the most pros­perous countries of the world, but that love of country is individual and not public-spirited, owing to the want of cohesion among the classes of the nation.

To show a real and national feeling of patriotism the Egyptians must adapt them­selves to the existing conditions by a wise and moderate policy. They most dearly recognise the obligation under which England has placed them by raising the country to a height of prosperity never attained by their forefathers, whose ambitions were easily satis­fied. But the present-day Egyptian is discon­tented with the progress which has been made possible to him.

When England occupied this country after the rebellion of Arabi the political change which robbed them of their independence was unwelcome. British influence grew year by year and after a quarter of a century the Egyptian nation opposes the occupying Power on one all-important point. The Egyptians assert their capability of assuming their own Government, and, on the other hand, England contends that the time is not yet ripe for them to stand alone.

But neither of these contentions, continues the writer, is beneficial to the people, and a moderate policy must be adopted by both sides. On our side, we should not deceive ourselves with illusive dreams. England could never withdraw white the country is in such a state of torpor. The British authorities, who took so strong a stand when every Euro­pean country was against them, will not retire now when their relations with all the Powers are so amicable.

On the other hand England would have no right in patting the Egyptians under a yoke of injustice, and in turning a deaf ear to their rightful deoMids. Let both nations act in harmony for the country’s weal, and with the progress of education the independ­ence of Egypt will be regained.
CORPORATION OF WESTERN
EGYPT, LIMITED.
The following circular letter has been issued to the shareholders

“Dear Sir (or Madam),—Important infor­mation relating to the trial crops of cotton grown on the newly reclaimed lands of the Corporation has now come to hand, and samples of three of the four varieties of Egypt­ian cotton cultivated this season have been received from Egypt and are open to inspec­tion by shareholders at the offices of the Corporation. These samples comprise : Yano- vitz cotton- Grown, headquarters, Khargeh Oasis, Bore I. ; planted, March 14-March 16, 1906. The bolls are not selected. They are the earliest ripened. This is the first cotton crop from land which was only last year re­claimed. Afifi cotton—Grown, headquarters, Khargeh Oasis, Bore I. ; planted, March 14 March 16, 1906 ; picked, August 14, 1906. The bolls are not selected. They are from those earliest ripened. This is the first cotton crop from land only last year brought under cultivation. Abbassi cotton— Grown, headquarters, Khargeh Oasis, Bore I. The first cotton crop from land brought under cultivation only last summer. Planted, March 14-Maroh 16, 1906 ; picked, August 14, 1906. The bolls are not selected They are from the earliest ripened. (N.B.—The comment is that of the agricultural chemist to the Corporation.)

“Ia view of the fact that cotton is now show­ing a profit of no less than £20 per feddan, the following valuation made in Egypt by cotton experts is significant of the return that may now be anticipated from the cultivation of cotton on a large scale on the reclaimed lands : Yanovitz, P.T. 425-460 per kantar ; Afifi, P.T. 410 per kantar ; Abbassi, P.T. 380 per kantar ; Ashmouni, P.T. 310 per kantar. The average price obtained for cotton in Egypt this year is P.T 350 per kantar. I give below a translation of a communication of interest received from Saad Bey Khalef, a wealthy landowner of Behera, one who is regarded as a judge in matters pertaining to the cultiva­tion of agricultural and cotton lands. He writes : ‘ I went to the offices of the Corpora­tion of Western Egypt (in Cairo) and saw the samples of cotton, and found them very good, especially the Afifi and Abbassi. Also I saw the samples of wheat and barley, and found them wonderfully good, being the first year’s produce, and I congratulate you on the good quality of the lands, as such good crops could not be got the first year except from first-class land.” This evidence is confirmatory of the statements respecting the quality of the soil made by the Corporation’s manager in the Oases and geological expert, and announced to the shareholders in a circular tetter some time since.- By order of the Board,
“Alfred W. DeEring, Secretary.
“115, Victoria Street, Westminster,
London, S.W.,
' October 27, 1906.”

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley (near Alexandria) half way to San Stefano
Ramleh's Fashionable Hotel.
Patronized by the Elite.
Full Pension P.T. 50 a day with Monthly Terms
Visitors from Cairo alight at Sidi Gaber.
Proprietor, C. AQUILINA, (Late of Thos Cook & Sons)

div.head: CONSTANTINOPLE NOTES.
div.p: THE MAHSOUSSEH COAL DEPOT.
(From our own Correspondent.)
Pera, November 5.

The Ottoman Admiralty Idas designated Lieutenant Dimitri Offend, adjutant to HE. Yank Offend Yoannidis, architect of the Admiralty, to proceed to Port Said to take delivery of the coal stores built by the Suez Canal Company for the Mahsonsseh Line. Lieutenant Dimitraki will he accompanied by Lieutenant Bekir Rashid Effendi, assistant- inspector of the line, who is now on a special mission to Suez.
Turkish Cotton.

The cultivation of cotton having proved a success in several provinces of the Empire, Selim Pasha Melbame. the Minister of Agri­culture, has decided to try Egyptian seed in the vilayets of Adana, Aidin, and Salonica, so as to improve the crop.
Egyptian Notable Decorated.
H.I.M. the Saltan has conferred the G old Medal of the Hedjaz Railway on Ahmed Bey Elfi, an Egyptian notable, who gave a hand­some subscription towards the construction of the Dew line.
Bulgar Cheese for Egypt.

A Bulgarian merchant has informed the Chamber of Commerce of Sofia that there is an excellent opening for Bulgarian cheese (kashkaval) in Egypt, and that this export trade only needs regular sea-communication. The Egyptian market can consume as much as 3,000,000 kilos of kashkaval yearly.
Envoy of the Negus.

M. A. Souroi, private secretary of the Negus, is now in Constantinople, and called on the Hellenic Minister, M. Gryparis. M. Sonroi is visiting the industrial centres of Europe with a view to adapting his experiences to the benefit of Abyssinia. He is leaving this week.
The Bank of Athens.

M. Jean Pesmazoglou, General Manager of the Bank of Athens, who is on his way to Alex­andria, has contributed £1,000, of which half was in the gift of the Bank, towards the fond for rebuilding the Evangheliki School of Smyrna. The Bank is to establish a branch at Smyrna.
NATIVE PRESS OPINION.
AGRICULTURE ESSENTIAL TO
PROSPERITY.

“The day when Egyptians abandon agri- fessions for other professions or industries will be the day when the riches of the country will be definitely seized by strangers. We shall become poor and abject, and those of us whom the lawyer’s gown has attracted will become a charge on the state, for the new holders of all the true wealth of the country will natnrally prefer to employ their oompatriots. Say as we will that the country needs in­struction, industries and arts, it none the less remains essentially agricultural on account of the extraordinary fertility of its soil and its great climatic and geographical advan­tages

“Our methods of cultivation are antiquated. Now that agriculture as a science has pro­gressed, we should be the first authorities on agriculture in the world, and it is in every way our interest to profit by new discoveries which will enable us to increase the total of our revenues and the yield of our crops. Bat it would seem that European civilisation has progressed too rapidly among us,for the scientific agriculturist has ended by considering him­self an inferior being. Oar young people are devoted to law and medicine, and a lamentable state of affairs has arisen. Longing for a pompons title or ornamental diploma, they sacrifice the most vital interests, and we can only express our genuine concern at the tendency that we note.” (“Al Minbar.”)
GRAND CONTINENTAL HOTEL.

By kind permission of Lieut. Colonel E.A. Herbert, M.V.O., and the officers, the Band 6th (Innikilling) Dragoons will perform the following programme to-morrow (Wednesday) during and after dinner. Judging by last week’s attendance, it is advisable to book tables beforehand.
March—L’Entente Cordiale—Allier.
Overture—Lyre d’Or—Herman.
Waltz—Nachtswaermer—Jets.
Selection—The Toreador—Caryll.
Dance—Grotesque—Glover.
Intermezzo—Russe—F mnks.
Waltz—Wintermaerchen—CzTbulka.
Grand Selection— Faust—Gounod,
Dance—The Dusky Minstrels—Burns. Intermezzo—Flirtation—Stock.
Selection—Veronique—Messager.
Two-step—Coontown Chimes—Webster.
Regimental March—Khedivial Anthem.
God Save the King.
Mr. J. Prosskr, Bandmaster.
STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
The 8.S. Adalia, of the Westcott and Lau rance Line, left Malta on Saturday, and is due here to-morrow with general cargo from London and coals from Newcastle.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Aziz Hassan, who has been paying a short visit to Caire, returned to Alexandria last night.

The Right Rev. Bishop Morley, D.D., Arch- deacon of the Church of England in Egypt, and Mrs. Morley arrived at Alexandria yester­day afternoon by the N.D.L. S.S. Schleswig. They are staying with Canon and Mrs. Alger­non Ward, 5 rue du Musee. His lordship and Mrs. Morley leave for Cairo to-morrow by the noon train.
The Hod. L. M. Iddings, American Diplo­matic Agent, came down to Alexandria yester-day to meet Mrs.and Miss Iddings.and returned with them to Cairo in the afternoon.

Sir Augustus Hemming and Lady Hemming are leaving London for Egypt in a few days. Sir Augustus was in the Colonial Office in Downi ng-street for thirty-six yearsbefore he con­ceived a fancy for administrative work on the spot. About his capability for such duties there could be not the slightest doubt From the routine of the department he had risen to be recognised as one of its ablest men, and had represented England on several boundary and other commissions.

Sir Augustus’s first Governorship was that of British Gaiana, but he was not there long when he was sent to Jamaica to succeed Sir Henry Blake, who had gone out to Hong Kong. He was Governor at Jamaica for eight years, retiring in 1904. Among other things, he did much to help West Indian cricket to reach its present position. Although over sixty, he has not altogether lost the prowess he was famed for when he kept wicket for the Gentlemen against the Players.

Vice-Admiral Arthar Charles Burgoyne Bromley, who served in the Abyssinian cam- pain of 1868. is staying at the Continental Hotel, Cairo. He was lieutenant of the Chal­lenger during the survey expedition of 1872-76.
M. Klobukowsky, the new French Diplomatic Agent at Cairo, will take up office on Decem­ber 12.
Signor Guido di Soragna, Italian Consul General at Cairo, left for Italy on Sunday by the S.S. Singapore.
Dr. Henry Goudy, Regins Professor of Civil Law in the University of Oxford, is compelled by illness to spend the winter abroad, and is now on his way to Egypt.

Mr. W. Tindall, who arrived yesterday morning by the Britannia, is staying at Ramleh with Mr. G. B. Alderson, and in a few days will go up to Thebes. Mr. Tindall is one of the best known Anglo Egyptian water- colour artists and intends to take home with him a large number of pictures for exhibition in London. He expects to remain in the country durirg the greater part of the season.

The Messageries S.S. Congo, which arrived from Marseilles to-day, had among her pas­sengers M. de la Booliniere, Comte de Lavizon, Mme de Martino, M. and Mme Poncet, Mme Legrand, Mme Jane Hading, M. and Mme Leblanc, Mme Rodocanachi, M. and Mme Durand.

Among those staying at the Tewfik Palace Hole1, Helouan, are Mr. F. d’Arcy, Mr. A. d’Aroy, Dr. Yeoman, Judge Bond, Capt. and Mrs. H. G. Lyons, Mr. Henry Eles, Mr. and Mrs. D. Robinson, Mr. A. S. Wylie, Mr. H Sawyer, Mr. A. Garrett, Mr. Forrest, Mr. Campbell, Mr. R. Hooper, Mr. A. S. Mills, and Mr. and Mrs. C. Carter.

Rooms have been booked at the same hotel by Baron and Barouess de Roseawerth, Mrs. Whitmaroh Philps, Miss E. H. Bell, the Mieses Abbott, Miss Susan D. Taite, and Count Galarza de Santa Clara, who will arrive very shortly.
Among the passengers by the North German Lloyd Schleswig, which arrived at Alex­andria from Marseilles yesterday, were Mrs.

L. M. Iddings, wife of the American Diplo­matic Agent, and Miss Betty Iddings Lady Anne Blunt, Countess and Mllede Zoghe Count de Galarza, Rev. and Mrs. Stephen Campbell, Mr. and Mrs. Jacques Aghion, the Misses Adrienne, Eugdnie and Renta Aghion, Capt.
